comments.commentBody:
Mr Pooch
You obfuscate as much as you want.
The reference Dan refers to is well-respected national study.
You may want magical calories but there is no such thing.
Weight loss occurs when calories out >> calories in.
Calories out comes from living and exercising and pooping... or in extreme cases cutting it off.
If you really want to lose weight and are prepared to look in the mirror - that is all the science you need - at least according to the real studies and weight loss strategies.
We need to learn to recite: No Magical Calories
She's well qualified to question and challenge the irrational mandates of uninformed elected public officials.  She knows more about Ebola than probably every elected official in the United States.
She's well qualified to question and challenge the irrational mandates of uninformed elected public officials.  She knows more about Ebola than probably every elected official in the United States.
I don't know but what those who had direct contact with American Ebola patients in the hospital are in quarantine at home just like she is.
I don't know but what those who had direct contact with American Ebola patients in the hospital are in quarantine at home just like she is.

One major factor is that these days, when you have an anesthetic, you have to have someone pick you up from the hospital. More and more people are single without close family and they're not comfortable talking to casual friends about the procedure. I know many people who would have gone if they'd had the option to take a cab or car service home.

I do not believe those tests are as effective  at detecting colon cancer as colonoscopies.A fellow commenter shared that colon cancer was missed by a sigmoidoscopy. aving colon cancer,chemotherapy,radiation,and dying are far more unpleasant than having a colonoscopy.My sister has colon cancer which was caught at stage Pre-1A upon routine screening colonoscopy at age  50.She needed surgery,and chemotherapy.Hopefully,she will survive.If colon cancer is not detected until someone is at a later stage,that person is more likely to die.I can not tell anyone else what to do.I only share my sister’s  decision to have a screening colonoscopy,a  decision which hopefully has saved her life.
The most powerful test is the one that people will use.  There are cheaper , less unpleasant alternatives to colonoscopy.
The most dangerous time is removing the protective gear.
The most dangerous time is removing the protective gear.

I think you aren't pragmatic enough Paul.

Oh, you try, and most of your readers appreciate that. Those who don't read here to keep track of the opposition, or, as they refer to their opponents, the lunatic fringe.

But a sad truth about humanity is that there are as many people who trust even false belief more than reason as there are who trust reason and distrust belief.

Football players take a knee to thank a god when they score; when was the last time you saw a running back take a knee to accept that same god's judgement that a 275 lb linebacker should stop him cold 10 yards behind the line of scrimmage and cost the game?

Humanity is peculiarly wired to to create belief systems, and some vest in them absolutely, even if it means running at full engines in an ocean known to be full of icebergs.

ISIS success in the middle east is the result of knowns: repressive, discriminatory, murderous government. Yet which of those governments have reacted to ISIS by materially changing?

The murder of children at Sandy Hook was met by NRA members with the suggestion that we don't have a problem with gun violence, we need more guns in schools and less gun regulation.

You've made the mistake of thinking well, Paul, and thinking that if economic theory works, and advantages the majority, even if to the disadvantage of a minority that's wealthy, then knowledge trumps belief.

Galileo thought knowledge trumped belief, too, and for that was formally imprisoned until his death.
.

3 observations:

1) Genetically modified foods have been BANNED in many countries. Genetically modified foods are a risk to the world's food supply. They should be banned here too not just labeled!

2) Since we've known about the dangers of mercury for very long time why does our government continue to ALLOW BP (British Petroleum) to dump mercury into Lake Michigan, the source of drinking water for millions of Americans?

3) Good article!

" why does our government continue to ALLOW BP (British Petroleum) to dump mercury into Lake Michigan, the source of drinking water for millions of Americans?" Because BP (and other corps) are the predators, we the prey.

Our Congresspeople's loyalties are to the predators, not to the prey. After all, the corporations protect them and feed them.

Please give one example, proven scientifically, that GMO's are a risk to health. The world's food supply benefits from seeds engineered to grow with less water, for instance, or seeds genetically engineered to duplicate seeds with a natural genetic resistance to crop killing fungus. GMO is a broad and varied term. Do your research in a varied way and I think you will discover seed geneticists  working for the benefit of those less fortunate.

I have three observations:
1) Heavy metal toxins are being discovered in more and more foods, e.g., cadmium in chocolate, mercury in fish, arsenic in water, etc.
2) These toxins are dangerous at lower and lower levels than previously thought.
3) No one is speaking out for adding heavy metal levels to food labeling, yet many people want genetically modified foods labeled as such despite abundant data showing their safety.

That's a big disconnect between what's dangerous to health and what isn't.
As I recall, the toxicity of arsenic varies with the valance of the arsenic and possibly if the arsenic compound is organic or inorganic,  I'll have to look into that and others should too.

Yes, she is liable.
No, she can't pay.

Yes, she is liable.
No, she can't pay.
A negative blood is not definitive or reliable, otherwise she wouldn't be in quarantine. The virus first goes to tissues like the spleen and incubates there, not in the blood.
A negative blood is not definitive or reliable, otherwise she wouldn't be in quarantine. The virus first goes to tissues like the spleen and incubates there, not in the blood.

A quick check, far from comprehensive, showed that the toxicity of arsenic trioxide and arsenic pentoxide (and presumably their salts) vary widely and are roughly comparable.  Arsenic +5 organic compounds are described as less toxic than arsenic +3.
You should research nurse Hickox's professional qualifications.  The pertinent parts are online.  She's well beyond a New Yorker article.
You should research nurse Hickox's professional qualifications.  The pertinent parts are online.  She's well beyond a New Yorker article.

"Haven't we done that only to have additional people exposed and/or infected?"
No!
The only people who have become infected were working directly with highly symptomatic patients. There's been a lot of media frenzy around re-tracing the steps of the people who eventually got sick, but zero evidence that they passed ebola on to anyone else.
The guidance she is violating is not meant to protect public health. It is meant to protect cynical politicians who need to assure a paranoid and scientifically illiterate public that they are "doing something."
Our household began using shower filters about a decade ago. A person inhales a lot of vapor during a shower.

Maybe from the improperly sealed water tower atop your building.
Pigeons probably got into the tower.

Actually, there's been a significant increase in rare lung conditions caused by nontuberculous mycobacterium (NTM), and researchers believe one of the main culprits may be aerosolized water, from shower heads in particular. Pigeons and water tanks are not the problem but biofilms formed by water in high rises is. Equally dangerous for some people are hot tubs and humidifiers. The only filter that can actually remove these so-called NTMs from faucets and shower heads is made by Pall Corporation, lasts for about two months, and costs about $60. Other filters are useless to filter out NTMs.

I, along with many others diagnosed with this serious, sometimes life-threatening condition, no longer take showers but only take baths. Unfortunately, treatment for NTM lung disease, which in many ways is like TB except is not contagious, is very toxic with limited success.

I am fairly sure that I caught my current serious lung condition, mycobacterium avium intracellulare, from my shower.  So, there's another thing to worry about as regards to water, especially in New York high rises.

"Haven't we done that only to have additional people exposed and/or infected?"
No!
The only people who have become infected were working directly with highly symptomatic patients. There's been a lot of media frenzy around re-tracing the steps of the people who eventually got sick, but zero evidence that they passed ebola on to anyone else.
The guidance she is violating is not meant to protect public health. It is meant to protect cynical politicians who need to assure a paranoid and scientifically illiterate public that they are "doing something."
She had a fever, that's why she first ended up in the hospital. Now she's at home with her boyfriend, so her tent problem is over.
She had a fever, that's why she first ended up in the hospital. Now she's at home with her boyfriend, so her tent problem is over.

Rob McConnell: I did read the Caral Ciccone piece and found it exactly as you describe. It was intended to embarass him, and was silly and pointless. The fact that she lied at the outset when meeting him that she knew his work should have been a red flag in terms of her character. Frankly his work and the quality and tone (amazing) of it is the reason people are reeling. It is the antithesis of aggressive or rude....and listeners understandably are shocked at the story - and very sad. Toronto is a film town and his interviews with major film stars, especially from the U.S. have been some of the best. And so it's sad to hear about this side and so so disappointing.
